results.title: Artificial illuminations
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description: In ‘Artificial illuminations’, Asher records the patterns, shadows, and traces of ambient light. Each glowing particle embodies a temporary life.

results.title: Sydney Harbour Bridge. Bondi. Sydney Bush. Cars
results.brief_description: A compilation of four experimental films made by filmmaker, Paul Winkler, between 1977 - 1980: “Sydney Harbour Bridge”, “Bondi”, “Sydney Bush” and “Cars”.

results.title: MIMA Yearbook. Vol. 1
results.brief_description: Volume one of a three volume set, this video compilation of excerpts from Australian film and video art covers the period from 1962-1980, and is a unique and tantalising entry into the non-mainstream history of Australian film and video.
results.description: Volume one of a three volume set, this video compilation of excerpts from Australian film and video art covers the period from 1962-1980, and is a unique and tantalising entry into the non-mainstream history of Australian film and video.

results.title: Rowing on the Yarra
results.brief_description: A beautifully photographed portrait of Melbourne’s busy Yarra River during the rowing season with the Hoddle Bridge and passing automobile traffic framing the background using timelapse cinematography. A nostalgic feel to the film is conveyed through the use of tinted monochrome colouring and a music soundtrack.

results.title: Stadium
results.brief_description:
Short experimental film capturing the atmosphere of Melbourne’s iconic MCG stadium at night whilst hosting a soccer match during the 2000 Sydney Olympics.
No commentary, using sound effects only.
results.description:
Short experimental film capturing the atmosphere of Melbourne’s iconic MCG stadium at night whilst hosting a soccer match during the 2000 Sydney Olympics.

results.title: Corps flottant
results.brief_description: Cahen’s film is a video essay of a transitory reality depicted through the rhythms of rural life in Japan. Men bathe in the thermal springs of Kusatu, while an elderly woman tends to a rice paddy. Cahen creates a dream-like chronicle of the landscape and develops a painterly impression of the figures who exist within that landscape.
results.description: Cahen’s film is a video essay of a transitory reality depicted through the rhythms of rural life in Japan. results.title: Meet the People
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description: Blurring the line between documentary and fiction, truth and artifice, Meet the People presents fourteen ‘characters’ who face the camera in talking head close-ups and speak about their lives and dreams. The intimacy and honesty of their fragmented, autobiographical storytelling is illusory; the credits reveal that these people are professional actors, playing fictional roles, reading a script. As Silver writes, this work points to a complicity on the part of the viewer in his desire to believe and identify with the traditions of and characters on TV. The same television that mimics a perfected form of the identity of the ‘average person’ is also in part responsible for creating this identity; it both researches, uses and manufactures this ‘average person’s‘ hopes and dreams. And so the question of a ‘real person’ becomes ‘real’ compared to what?
